title: Landesliga
text:
The Landesliga () is a tier of <a href="Association%20football">football</a> in some states of the <a href="German%20football%20league%20system">German football league system</a>.
In <a href="Bavaria">Bavaria</a>, <a href="Saxony">Saxony</a>, <a href="Thuringia">Thuringia</a>, <a href="Bremen">Bremen</a>, <a href="Lower%20Saxony">Lower Saxony</a> and <a href="Hamburg">Hamburg</a>, the Landesligas are set right below the <a href="Oberliga%20%28football%29">Oberliga</a> and therefore are the sixth tier. The reason for this is that Bavaria, Hamburg, Lower Saxony, and Bremen are the only places in Germany where the Oberliga, the <a href="States%20of%20Germany">State</a>, and the <a href="Umbrella%20organization">Verband</a> are geographically the same, while the other two states simply chose to call their leagues "Landesligas" when establishing them in 1990. In the Middle Rhine and Lower Rhine regions of <a href="North%20Rhine-Westphalia">North Rhine-Westphalia</a> it is also, since 2012, the sixth tier.
In <a href="Baden-W%C3%BCrttemberg">Baden-Württemberg</a>, <a href="Rhineland-Palatinate">Rhineland-Palatinate</a> (southwestern part only), <a href="North%20Rhine-Westphalia">North Rhine-Westphalia</a> (Westphalia), <a href="Mecklenburg-Western%20Pomerania">Mecklenburg-Western Pomerania</a>, <a href="Brandenburg">Brandenburg</a>, <a href="Saxony-Anhalt">Saxony-Anhalt</a>, and <a href="Berlin">Berlin</a>, the Landesliga is the seventh tier, below the <a href="Verbandsliga">Verbandsliga</a>. In the <a href="Saarland">Saarland</a>, the Landesligas are set as the eighth tier.
Typically, in each <a href="States%20of%20Germany">Bundesland</a>, the "Landesligas" are divided into different "Staffeln" or "divisions". In Bavaria, the "Landesliga" is divided into five divisions, South-West, South-East, Central, North-West, and North-East. In Saxony, Bremen, and Thuringia, the Landesliga is in a single division format. In Hamburg, it consists of two divisions.
In 2017, <a href="Schleswig-Holstein">Schleswig-Holstein</a> introduced Landesligas at the sixth tier, leaving <a href="Hesse">Hesse</a> as the only German state not to have Landesligas. The Rheinland region of <a href="Rhineland-Palatinate">Rhineland-Palatinate</a> also operates without such a league. 
In Brandenburg, Mecklenburg-Western Pomerania, Saxony, Saxony-Anhalt, and Thuringia the league below the Landesligas is the Landesklasse (). Also in 2017, Mecklenburg-Western Pomerania reduced the number of Landesligas and Landesklasses to 2 and 4 divisions respectively, but temporarily reverted them to 3 and 5 divisions for one season in 2020.
Leagues.
Tier-VI Landesligas.
Of the 69 "Landesligas" in Germany 20 are set at tier six of the <a href="German%20football%20league%20system">German football league system</a>, these being:
Tier VII-Landesligas.
Apart from the above-mentioned states, Landesligas also exist in the states of <a href="Baden-W%C3%BCrttemberg">Baden-Württemberg</a>, <a href="Rhineland-Palatinate">Rhineland-Palatinate</a> (in the southwest part only), <a href="North%20Rhine-Westphalia">North Rhine-Westphalia</a> (Westphalia), <a href="Mecklenburg-Western%20Pomerania">Mecklenburg-Western Pomerania</a>, <a href="Brandenburg">Brandenburg</a>, <a href="Saxony-Anhalt">Saxony-Anhalt</a>, <a href="Berlin">Berlin</a> and as Landesklasse, in <a href="Saxony">Saxony</a> and <a href="Thuringia">Thuringia</a> as tier seven leagues, below the Verbandsligas:
Tier VIII-Landesligas.
Uniquely, the <a href="Saarland">Saarland</a> has the Landesligas as the eighth tier of its league system; in Brandenburg, Mecklenburg-Western Pomerania and Saxony-Anhalt the equivalent tier is Landesklasse.
